summary: This document is an email chain from June 13-14, 2019, between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discussing the draft indictment of Jeffrey Epstein. The prosecutors debate how much detail to include, balancing the need to demonstrate the case's seriousness with protecting victim identities and preserving investigative details for witness vetting.

persons.name: Geoff
persons.role: Spokesperson or official expected to discuss the case publicly
persons.context: Mentioned as someone who will need material to discuss the significance of the case at a press conference.

events.title: Drafting of Epstein Indictment
events.description: Prosecutors in the Southern District of New York are finalizing a draft indictment against Jeffrey Epstein, debating the level of detail to include about victims and evidence.

events.title: Arrest by SDNY
events.description: The upcoming arrest of Jeffrey Epstein by the Southern District of New York is referenced as an event that will itself demonstrate the case's seriousness.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Prosecutors were actively drafting an indictment against Jeffrey Epstein in June 2019, prior to his arrest by SDNY.
There was internal debate about how much victim detail to include, with concerns about protecting victim anonymity and preserving investigative advantages.
One argument for withholding details was to prevent future witnesses from fabricating testimony based on publicized information.
Prosecutors considered adding paragraphs about the volume of victims, search warrant evidence, and victims' financial circumstances to 'bulk up' the indictment.
The correspondence shows strategic planning for the public presentation of the case, including a press conference.
